definition: high in score but low in ability (as a result of teaching to the test)
high/tall/above average/loud/your (honorific)
surname Gao
part/share/ingredient/component

to divide/to separate/to distribute/to allocate/to distinguish (good and bad)/part or subdivision/fraction/one tenth (of certain units)/unit of length equivalent to 0.33 cm/minute (unit of time)/minute (angular measurement unit)/a point (in sports or games)/0.01 yuan (unit of money)
low/beneath/to lower (one's head)/to let droop/to hang down/to incline
surname Neng
can/to be able to/might possibly/ability/(physics) energy

sentences.english: The result is that Chinese college graduates often have high scores but low ability.
sentences.chinese: 结果是，中国的大学毕业生通常高分低能。

sentences.english: Some time ago, a new phrase "high marks but poor competence" came into being.
sentences.chinese: 前段时间，社会上出现了一个新词“高分低能”。

definition: exam-oriented education/teaching to the test
to have high standards but little ability/to be fastidious but incompetent (idiom)
weak student
low marks/low score
higher education record/record including Master's or Doctoral degree
one who is successful in one's studies, can become an official (idiom)
to take an exam
all-round education (contrasted with 應試教育|应试教育[ying4 shi4 jiao4 yu4], exam-oriented education)
top student
to overemphasize some topic (at the expense of others)/overdoing it/to go overboard
"exam master", sb who takes many exams and aces all of them
(slang) to rely on one's father's wealth or prestige to get ahead
those who did not benefit from the Chinese economic reforms of the 1980s/see also 富二代[fu4 er4 dai4]
force feeding (as a teaching method)
bookworm/pedant/bookish fool
(coll.) adults still living with and depending on their parents
